statement.text: Break-even analysis determines the level of a key variable (sales, price, cost) at which NPV equals zero, indicating the minimum required performance for value creation.
statement.formal: NPV = 0 = -I₀ + Σ[CF(Q*) / (1+r)^t], solve for Q* (break-even quantity)

explanation.intuition: Break-even analysis answers the question: What minimum level of sales (or other variable) do we need to justify this investment? It provides a clear target for management.
explanation.key_insight: NPV break-even differs from accounting break-even. Accounting break-even covers costs but destroys value because it ignores opportunity cost of capital. NPV break-even requires covering both costs and cost of capital.
explanation.technical_details: Three types of break-even exist: (1) Cash break-even - covers cash costs only, (2) Accounting break-even - covers all costs including depreciation, (3) NPV break-even - covers all costs plus opportunity cost of capital.
common_misconceptions: Accounting break-even is sufficient - it destroys value by ignoring capital costs
Break-even is the same regardless of discount rate - higher discount rates raise NPV break-even
Break-even analysis is only for sales quantity - applies to any key variable

definitions_glossary.cash_break_even: Sales level where cash inflows equal cash outflows
definitions_glossary.accounting_break_even: Sales level where revenue equals all costs including depreciation
definitions_glossary.npv_break_even: Sales level where project NPV equals zero
definitions_glossary.contribution_margin: Revenue minus variable costs per unit

sources.citation: Brealey, R., Myers, S., & Allen, F. (2020). Principles of Corporate Finance. 13th Edition. McGraw-Hill.
Ross, S., Westerfield, R., & Jaffe, J. (2019). Corporate Finance. 12th Edition. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Calculate cash, accounting, and NPV break-even points
Understand why NPV break-even exceeds accounting break-even
Apply break-even analysis to project risk assessment
Use break-even to evaluate operating leverage
prerequisites: Understanding of fixed and variable costs

variables.EAC: Equivalent annual cost of initial investment

examples.scenario: Investment=$1M, 5-year life, r=10%. FC=$100k/yr, P=$50, VC=$30. Depreciation=$200k/yr.
